author: The Telegraph
title: Events in Ireland: music, arts and adventure
text: Visit Ireland at any time of year and you’ll find a big event or two going on, celebrating anything from traditional Irish music, arthouse film or craft beer to Fifties rock ’n’ roll. Dublin this autumn and the festival season Dublin Festival Season is an exciting period to discover the city. In the month of September, the capital is abuzz with different events and lively locals celebrating their unique culture. Fashionistas flock to the capital between 7 and 13 September, when more than 250 retailers, bars and hotels join forces for Dublin Fashion Festival. It’s not just an opportunity to kit yourself out with the latest collections – there’s a full roster of talks, workshops and street catwalk shows. Tiger Dublin Fringe also kicks off on 7 September, showcasing the best of Irish and international talent in music, theatre, comedy and the arts (until 20 September). In the month of September, the capital is abuzz with different events and lively locals If you can choose one date, head into the city for Culture Night (18 September), when scores of museums, galleries and historic houses throw open their doors for exclusive guided tours and talks. Hop on two wheels for a bike tour, join in outdoor events and watch performances across the city – all without paying a penny. It is the perfect welcome to the Republic of Ireland’s friendly capital. Arts, music and traditional dancing Elsewhere in Ireland, you’ll find festivals that belong in the first rank of European cultural events. Kilkenny Arts Festival (7-16 August) always lives up to its goal of offering “artistic adventures in Ireland’s medieval city”. Highlights of this year’s line-up are DruidShakespeare , a re-telling of Shakespeare’s history plays from an Irish perspective, and Eternal Harmony, a unique series of 18 concerts presenting the music of Johann Sebastian Bach. If you’d like an introduction to traditional Irish music, you won’t do any better than Fleadh Cheoil na hÉireann (9-16 August) when Sligo will reverberate to the sound of guitar, fiddle, pipes and bodhrán. A competition pitting the biggest Irish musicians against each other, this is where new standards of traditional Irish music evolve and where visitors can complement their music education by enjoying traditional folk dancing. Irish jig: visitors to Fleadh Cheoil na hÉireann can enjoy traditional folk dancing Don’t forget to make the most of the seaside town’s beautiful location, visiting Irish author WB Yeats’ tomb, located nearby, and hiking in the verdant countryside. Jazz enthusiasts will be converging on Cork for the Guinness Jazz Festival (23-26 October). Confirmed acts for 2015 include two Grammy-winners – Marcus Miller and Cassandra Wilson – and the Darius Brubeck Quartet. Known as the “rebel city”, for backing the York claim to the throne in the English War of the Roses, Cork is a beautiful spot to explore and is famed for its foodie scene, not least the English Market, packed with local produce. Oysters, horses and ghosts Racing aficionados shouldn’t miss the Galway Races (7-9 September). The Galway Plate, on the Wednesday, has been contested since 1869. Later in the year, Galway hosts its famous Oyster and Seafood Festival (24-27 September), incorporating the world oyster-opening championships and a masquerade ball. Why not enjoy some Halloween fun in Derry-Londonderry? The Banks of the Foyle Halloween Carnival is a huge event each year with spooky happenings, live music and fireworks (31 October). Robots, seafood and premieres in Northern Ireland In recent years, Northern Ireland has gained much-deserved acclaim for its fine food and drink, and boasts an oyster festival of its own in the village of Hillsborough, just 12 miles south of Belfast (1-6 September). As well as a packed programme of gastronomic events, it includes the Oyster Masters Golf Day at nearby Lisburn Golf Club. To discover the perfect accompaniment to the locally sourced seafood, make a detour to Bushmills Salmon and Whiskey Festival (18-20 September). Expect live music, storytelling, some eye-popping acrobatics and a fair degree of clowning about A highlight of Belfast's cultural calendar, the Belfast International Arts Festival features a host of performances across the city from theatre, dance and music to contemporary visual arts. The final line-up is yet to be announced, but the UK and Ireland premiere of Hallo, by Swiss choreographer and clown Martin Zimmerman, and South Indian show The Kitchen, a feast for the senses which ends with the audience being fed, are already confirmed. Meanwhile, Titanic Belfast is fighting off a mechanised invasion. Robots is an exciting exhibition at the spectacular dockside venue, featuring some of the most iconic androids and cyborgs from the big screen – including R2D2, the Terminator T-800 and RoboCop (until 13 September). In Derry-Londonderry, the Carnival of Colours will transform St Columb’s Park into a giant multi-ring circus (29-30 August). Expect live music and storytelling, some eye-popping acrobatics and a fair degree of clowning about! • Come and find your holiday inspiration at ireland.com 'Live in the now' in Ireland Savour every second in Ireland, where the natural beauty, the culture and the people all seem to exist together in a timeless moment. Discover how to embrace life by 'living in the now' and enhance your encounters, whether you're in one of Ireland's great cities or out in the wonderful wilds.
